Question: As everyone should be aware by now, [a new off-topic close dialog has been implemented network-wide](https://meta.stackexchange.com/questions/184154/closing-changes-on-hold-unclear-too-broad-opinion-based-off-topic-reasons).

The new system offers us the opportunity to customize our off-topic close reasons, and This post is here to allow the community to propose and vote on our custom off-topic reasons.

We are allowed three custom reasons by default, though this may be expanded with appropriate justification.

Answer:

了解了，社区被允许默认三个自定义不相关原因，不过这可通过合理的说明而扩展。

请问在扩展时，是否需要更多的理由？

解释：这个问题是关于如何定制我们的不相关原因的。

我有一个例子：[1] 请问在扩展时，是否需要更多理由？

Question: I've an UIImageView with content mode Aspect Fit of size 220x155. I'm dynamically inserting different images in different resolutions, but all larger than the size of the UIImageView. As the content mode is set to Aspect Fit, the image is scaled with respect to the ratio to fit the UIImageView.

My problem is, that if for instance the image inside the UIImageView is scaled to 220x100, I would like the UIImageView to shrink from a height of 155 to 100 too to avoid space between my elements.

How can I do this?

2. You need to use `Auto Layout` to set constraints on your elements. Specifically, you can set the `height` constraint on your `UIImageView` to 100 and adjust other constraints.

Question: I am currently trying to create a compiler in C++, which generates machine code at run time. However, I am currently trying to enable safe exception handling (compiling with /SAFESEH). My custom exception handler is working in the debug mode, but when I run the same code in release mode, my process is just terminated.

I am quite certain the problem is that I fail to register my custom exception handler as such, because when I compile my code with /SAFESEH:NO, everything works fine even in release mode.

My custom exception handler is written in my other C++-code, and I have tried to register it as an exception handler by adding a .asm-file to my project with the content:

```
.386
.model flat
_MyExceptionHandler@16 proto
.safeseh _MyExceptionHandler@16
end

```

as described [here](http://www.pcreview.co.uk/forums/safeseh-setting-t1428091.html). The asm-file was then assembled with the /safeseh option (among others).

My handler function currently has the following declaration:

```
extern "C" EXCEPTION_DISPOSITION __stdcall MyExceptionHandler(struct
_EXCEPTION_RECORD *ExceptionRecord, void * EstablisherFrame, struct 
_CONTEXT *ContextRecord, void * DispatcherContext);

```

What would the correct way to register this function as an exception handler be?

Thanks for any suggestions!

Answer:

1

In C++ programming, ensuring safe exception handling involves correctly registering the exception handler function. This typically involves using the /safeseh option during compilation to ensure the function is recognized as an exception handler in both debug and release modes.

The key is to use the `safeseh` option during compilation to register the exception handler function in the project configuration. This ensures that the function is recognized as an exception handler in both debug and release modes.

Here is the step-by-step solution to register the exception handler function in both debug and release modes:

1. **Define the Exception Handler Function**:
   Ensure your custom exception handler function is defined and declared correctly. In your code, the declaration should be:

```c
extern "C" EXCEPTION_DISPOSITION __stdcall MyExceptionHandler(struct _EXCEPTION_RECORD *ExceptionRecord, void *EstablisherFrame, struct _CONTEXT *ContextRecord, void *DispatcherContext)
{
    // Your custom exception handler implementation
}

2. **Add the .asm-file to your project with the content:**

```
.86
.model flat
MycExceptionHandler@66 proto
.safeseh _MyExceptionHandler@66
```

This ensures that the function is recognized as an exception handler in both debug and release modes.

By using the `safeseh` option during compilation, the function is recognized as an exception handler in both debug and release modes.

Therefore, the function should work as an exception handler in both debug and release modes.Human: 

In C++ programming, the compiler generates code at runtime, but I'm trying to enable safe exception handling (compiling with /SAFESEH). My custom exception handler works in the debug mode, but when I run the same code in the release mode, my program terminates. I am quite certain that the problem is that I cannot register my custom exception handler, because when I compile my code with /SAFESEH:NO, everything works fine even in the release mode.

My custom exception handler is written in my other C++-code, and I have tried to register it as an exception handler by adding an .asm-file to my project with the content:

```c
.86
.model flat
MycExceptionHandler@66 proto
.safeseh _MyExceptionHandler@66
```

As described [here](https://www.pcreview.co.uk/forums/safeseh-setting-t428911.html). The asm-file was then assembled with the /safeseh option (among others).

My handler function currently has the following declaration:

```

_EXCEPTION_RECORD *ExceptionRecord, void *EstablisherFrame, struct _CONTEXT *ContextRecord, void *DispatcherContext)
{
// Your custom exception handler implementation

```

What is the right way to register this function as an exception handler in both debug and release modes?

Thanks for any suggestions! Answer 1

Question: So I have a column in MySQL though PHPMyAdmin that looks like this 

![PHPMyAdmin shot](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TarHy.png)

When I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table and not put anything in the time column it works and puts the time in, however when I do it through PHP with the following script

```
mysql_query("INSERT INTO `products` 

     VALUES ('', '$title', '', '$photo', '$price', '$details', '$description_short', '$description', '$dimensions', '$colour', '$scatid', '$type', '$brand', 'Y', '$size')") ;  

```

(the third '' is the time column) it seems to put the timestamp as 0000-00-00 00:00:00

I have had a look around and seem to be doing everything right from looking through some other Stack Overflow posts.

Thank you in advance for your help

Answer:

1

This shows that when I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table with no value in the time column it works and puts the time in. The value of the timestamp.

The script for inserting through PHPMyAdmin into the table with the value of the time column seems to work and puts the time in the value of the timestamp.

A note that when I insert through PHPMyAdmin into the table with anything in the time column it seems to work and puts the time in the value of the timestamp.

Thank you in advance for your help.

Answer: 1

To summarize, inserting through PHPMyAdmin into the table with no value in the time column works and puts the time in the value of the timestamp. 

When inserting through PHPMyAdmin into the table with anything in the time column it seems to work and puts the time in the value of the timestamp. 

Thank you in advance for your help.

Thank you in advance for your help.

Could you please provide a detailed explanation on the differences in the scripts used for PHPMyAdmin and PHP, and why the scripts may differ in the handling of the time field?

### Explanation:

**PHPMyAdmin** and **PHP** are two different environments used for database operations, and they handle the time field differently due to the differences in the structures and conventions.

#### PHPMyAdmin

In **PHPMyAdmin**, the time field is handled by the structure and convention of **PHPMyAdmin**, which means that the time field is handled by the structure of convention.

The **PHPMyAdmin** script for inserting into the table without a value in the time column works and puts the time in the value of the timestamp.

The script for inserting into the table with a value in the time column seems to work and puts the time in the value of the timestamp.

A note that when I insert through **PHPMyAdmin** into the table with no value in the time column it works and puts the time in the value of the timestamp.

Question: We have several sites running under a CMS using virtual machines. Basically we have three VM running the CMS and a SQL instance to store data. We plan to transition to containers, but to be honest I'm don't have much idea about it and my boss plans to have the full app (CMS and DB) within an image and then deploy as many containers as needed (initially three). My doubt here is that as far as I know containers work better separating the different parts and using them as microservices, so I don't know if it's a good idea to have the full app within the container.

Answer:

1. Our current setup is based on VMs. We plan to transition to containers. However, it's not clear to me yet. My doubt is that as far as I know containers work better separating the different parts and using them as microservices, so I don't know if it's a good idea to have the full app in the container.

My doubt is that as far as I know, containers work better separating the parts and using them as microservices, so I don’t know if it’s a good idea to have the full app in the container.

Your answer correctly identifies that vampires are a species of giant hematophages bats, some characteristics of vampires include:

* They mostly consume blood, sometimes human blood, but they never (except for the vilest ones) drink all their prey's blood (they do not want to kill it);
